In case that Bitbucket Server is integrated with external directories, remember-me token should be ignored when the requiresPasswordChange attribute is set to true in the Crowd directory.

h3. Environment
 * Bitbucket Server 4.9.0
 * Crowd 2.9.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Integrate Bitbucket Server with Crowd
 # Log in Bitbucket Server with a user (User A) and then, check "Remember my login on this computer"
 # Restart the browser
 # Access Bitbucket Server with the same browser

h3. Expected Results

Bitbucket Server should show login page and need User A to input the credentials
h3. Actual Results

User A could log in without any authentication.
h3. Notes
 * The above actual results might cause some troubles in the following scenario{panel}_In case that there are some password leakages, an admin of the external directories wants the users to update their passwords immediately._
 # In the past, User A logged in Bitbucket Server with checking "Remember my login on this computer"
 # An admin of Crowd notices that a password of User A was leakked
 # The admin access Crowd, open user setting page of User A and set an attribute called "requiresPasswordChange" as "true" (It would require User A to update the password when the next login.)
 # In spite of the above setting, User A can login Bitbucket Server without updating the password{panel}
* JIRA, Confluence and Bamboo behave as well at this moment

h3. Workaround

Disabling remember-me token is only the workaround.
fields.summary: When a password in an external directory is reset, Administrators should have an option to invalidate 'remember me' tokens

When force push is a normal and expected part of the development process, links to JIRA issues can naturally become invalid.  However, they are not automatically removed when a commit that is removed has a JIRA issue id in the commit message.

Steps to duplicate:
 # Push 3 separate commits with different JIRA issue ID's to Bitbucket
 # In JIRA look up the three issues and the Development panel will have the links back to Bitbucket.  This is the expected behavior
 # Locally, reset refs/head back to the first commit.  Make a change and then force push the commit to Bitbucket
 # In JIRA look up the three issues and you will see that all of them still have links to the now defunct and unused commits.

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserverkb/reindex-jira-issue-keys-779171709.html] outlines the steps to force JIRA to reindex these links. However, this is a very manual, tedious process that must be performed when Bitbucket is down so as to guarantee that we don't interfere with normal concurrent access to the repository being cleaned up. 

Please add to the application the ability for Bitbucket to handle this re-index automatically without requiring the service to be stopped, the manual deletion of files on the server, and a new commit to the repository for the index to be initiated.
fields.summary: Update index to Jira issues when force push invalidates the link

fields.description:
In order to create a new repository, you must now assign it to a project, whether it's to an existing project or to a new one. When you land on the "Create a new repository" screen, you are able to select or create a project, however this is actually quite difficult to accomplish if you have many projects:

If you want to add the repository to an existing project, you have to manually scroll through the list until you find it. Even then, the order of said list appears to be in chronological order, whereas if I know the specific name, then it would be more feasible to have the list ordered via titles. Better still, a search functionality would be great, so you can jump straight to it rather than attempting to scroll through the list manually.

If you want to create a new project, the button to do so can be found when you scroll down to the bottom of the list. However as the content is loaded in dynamically and then appended, this pushes the button further down, meaning that you have to scroll down again to reach it, but the same thing happens. Only until you reach the very end of the list, you are then able to click it. If you have a lot of projects, then this can take some time to reach. A viable solution to this would be to have the button at the top of the list instead, so there's no need to even scroll to reach it.

Finally, if you have accidentally clicked on a project name whilst searching, you have to start all the way back from the beginning of the list. Here, I would expect the list to jump to the position of the selection, but unfortunately it doesn't.

As a regular user who creates many repositories, this can actually be quite frustrating, and so is a good example of poor UX.
fields.summary: Selecting/Creating Project when Creating New Repository

When we come back to check the changes they made, we normally can't remember what changes we asked for exactly. This is a large scale application and with so many developers. 

So if the file we commented is changed, we no longer can see the comment or the task unless you go to 'Activity' tab which only shows you the outdated code. We need to have 2 window side by side one with outdated code and the other with the new code to compare.

I wish we could see what file we made the comment and or created task against in the top where the changed files are listed as part of that PR. 

Then by just clicking the button in front of the file, that we created task for, we could see both outdated one from the activity and the new one side-by-side. 

The current side-by-side difference only shows the difference with the target branch to be merged in not with the previous commit

I know it is very hard to find what line of code we made comment against to display that as the new commit may have radically changed the file but displaying the whole file including the comment/task we created is possible.

2. often the file(s) in the "upstream" repository appear far down in the search results below the acres of user forks

fields.description:
In --BSERV-3001--, an option was created to turn of CAPTCHA completely. However, in an ideal world it seems you could disable CAPTCHA for specific types of users.

Consider a setup where you have two types of users
 # Users managed by an external system such as Active directory. Active directory already has a policy of locking the account after X attempts, so bitbucket server does not need CAPTCHA to protect against brute force attacks for these users.
 # Users built inside bitbucket server's internal directory (such as Atlassian's recommendation that you always keep an administrator or sysadmin account active in the Bitbucket Server internal directory) You would like CAPTCHA to protect these accounts.

For users in group #1, the CAPTCHA is a huge annoyance. If they get locked out of AD, there is now a two step process
 # Unlock AD account
 # Fill out bitbucket server CAPTCHA

This approach really doesn't scale if every Atlassian tool uses it. A locked password could potentially require you to
 # Unlock in AD
 # CAPTCHA for bitbucket server
 # CAPTCHA for bamboo
 # CAPTCHA for jira
 # ... (at some point you lose the point of having a centralized ID unlock mechanism)

At this point you would be tempted to turn off CAPTCHA entirely, but it's a bad idea because people could then brute force the accounts built in the internal directory.

The ideal solution seems to be the ability to turn off CAPTCHA only for users that are managed by an external user directory - is that possible?
fields.summary: Option to disable CAPTCHA for directory users

fields.description:
*Backstory*
My team encourages submitting PRs for review before they are ready to be merged to promote early collaboration and feedback. We were getting PRs come in on the last day of the sprint that needed A LOT of work before they could be merged. Right now, our strategy to indicate an In Progress PR is to include "WIP" or "DO NOT MERGE" in the PR Title / Description fields. 

*Problem*
This naming strategy works most of the time, but sometimes we have In Progress PRs that are getting merged into our main branch early. 

*Suggestion*
When I submit a PR for review before I am ready for that PR to be merged, I would like to mark that PR as "Needs Work" until I am ready to merge it. Once I am ready to merge it, I would like to remove this status so that others know to go through it one last time and approve it if the code adheres to our guidelines. I wouldn't want to mark my own PR as "Accepted", because that would probably mess with our current requirement of having two reviewers accept the PR before it can be merged. However, if something went horribly wrong, I might want to mark my own PR as "Declined".
fields.summary: Mark my own PRs as Needs Work or Declined

fields.description:
In order to increase the memory that Bitbucket Server uses, the admin must edit the {{setenv.sh}} script in the application install directory. Unfortunately, that means the settings must be re-applied on each upgrade. Provide a way to change the setting that will be persisted across upgrades.

Original suggestion:

It would be nice, if the setenv.sh would first check whether JVM_MINIMUM_MEMORY and JVM_MAXIMUM_MEMORY variables are set and if not, it creates with default values. This would allow to set JVM parameters in the init.d script and would ease the upgrade procedure.

*Workaround*
Set {{JVM_MINIMUM_MEMORY}} and {{JVM_MAXIMUM_MEMORY}} permanently as environmental variables. This will persist across upgrades without any script modification needed. This is also true for {{JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS}}.
fields.summary: Ability to set JVM arguments so they are persisted across upgrades

For example, a BitBucket Server git repository "my-git-repo" has a commit with the author reported as "Mickey Mouse". There is no account for "Mickey Mouse" in BitBucket Server. Which authenticated user put that commit on the BitBucket Server?

We are not looking for push traceability. We are looking for tool integrity concerning accountability in maintenance of company source code.

Currently, users can create commits as another team member (or any entity with access) and push those commits to the bitbucket server without accountability. 

This poses a risk to customers.

Increasing log levels and/or tracking IP is not sufficient.

h3. Summary

When checking the status of Elasticsearch, the service appears not be to running even if the Code search functionality is working.

 

h3. Environment
* Unix based operating system



h3. Steps to Reproduce
# run the {{service atlbitbucket_search status}} command



h3. Expected Results

The command returns:

{{Bitbucket-Search is running}}


h3. Actual Results

The command returns:

{{Bitbucket-Search is *not* running}}


h3.Workaround
Update the {{/etc/init.d/atlbitbucket_search}} script to check for the expected pid file location.

Currently the pid location is defined as:

{{PIDFILE=<Bitbucket Installation Directory>/bin/elasticsearch.pid}}

While it should be:

{{PIDFILE=<BITBUCKET_HOME>/shared/search/elasticsearch.pid}}

 

Where <Bitbucket Installation Directory> and <BITBUCKET_HOME> are the explicit values of the Bitbucket Installation and home directory.
fields.summary: The status of the atlbitbucket_search service returns "Bitbucket-Search is not running" even if the process is up and running

2016-08-04 03:30:13,935 ERROR [main] c.a.b.i.backup.client.BackupMain A backup could not be created

We would like to have this configuration at the project level that has a default value (same as today) but is configurable by sys admin (or even the project admin) to change the base location for the repos of that project. Whatever makes sense from there (like

Description: As a system administrator of bitbucket over many different groups in a bitbucket server instance, I would like to be able to have hooks that have a property where they can be edited and enabled only by system administrators so that we can support
 all the different groups and make sure one group doesn't impact others when a mistake is made.

We would like this as a configuration for all hooks so that the specific ones of Max Commit Size and Force Push can be set by our system administrators and NOT be changed by a project admin. This is a proactive attempt to maintain support with the small size
 sys admin team. When Git LFS is used, if not configured correctly then large binaries will be put on the repo and the effort to clean up is large. We are open to other ways to be able to set things like max commit size and no force pushes allowed at the global
 level but this seems like one potential easy way to set it up.
fields.summary: Allow sysadmins to enforce Git hook configurations

When the "Transcode diffs" feature is enabled for a repository, if the repository contains binary files (PNGs, for example), diffing any binary file will leak two file handles. Non-binary files do not leak handles.

This issue was fixed in Bitbucket Server 4.0.0 as a side effect of code changes made as part of the Java 8 and Guava 18 upgrades that were done in that major release. As a result, this issue only affects Stash 3.x and does not affect any version of Bitbucket Server.

As Stash 3.11 is well past its support window for bugs that are not security related, the fix for this issue will not be backported. Administrators which encounter this issue should upgrade to Bitbucket Server, which includes the fix. Workarounds for Stash 3.x administrators are:
* Disable "Transcode diffs", to prevent leaked descriptors
* Increase the maximum open files for the Stash {{java}} process and periodically restart it to clear leaked handles
fields.summary: Diff transcoding leaks file handles

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In Bitbucket Data Center instances, the bundled {{bitbucket-tag}} plugin re-indexes tags in repositories on all cluster nodes after every repository change. In extreme cases where repository changes are very frequent and/or tag re-indexing is very slow, this work can delay other, higher priority, work that runs on the same threads, such as cluster-wide invalidations of Hibernate and Atlassian-cache caches.  This can lead to caches becoming inconsistent on different cluster nodes for an extended period of time.

h3. Symptoms

If affected, certain state (such as the set of comments visible on a pull request) may be inconsistent when viewed on different cluster nodes. The inconsistency may last for several minutes or (in extreme cases) even longer, before eventually fixing itself without further action.

While affected, monitoring of the {{com.hazelcast:name=HazelcastInstance.EventService}} statistics over JMX (as described in [this page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/enabling-jmx-counters-for-performance-monitoring-776640189.html]) will show the {{eventQueueSize}} value, which should normally be close to 0, grow to very large values for an extended period of time. Alternatively, enabling the following properties

{noformat}
hazelcast.health.monitoring.level=NOISY
hazelcast.health.monitoring.delay=300
logging.logger.com.hazelcast.util.HealthMonitor=TRACE
logging.logger.com.hazelcast.internal.monitors.HealthMonitor=INFO
{noformat}

and restarting the instance will continuously log lines to {{atlassian-bitbucket.log}} of the form:

{noformat}
2016-08-04 11:58:14,956 INFO  [hz.hazelcast.HealthMonitor]  c.h.internal.monitors.HealthMonitor ... event.q.size=...
{noformat}

While affected, the {{event.q.size}} value in this line will grow to very large values for an extended period of time.

h3. Workaround

Log in as a system administrator, go to *Administration* >> *Manage add-ons*, and select the System add-ons. Find the "Bitbucket Server - Tag" plugin, and disable it. *Note*: The display of tags in the commit list (as described under "Quickly see work done by using tags" in [this page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Stash+3.5+release+notes]) will be impaired while this workaround is in effect.
h3. Solution

Upgrade to Bitbucket Data Center 4.9.0 or higher.
fields.summary: Heavy tag indexing load may lead to long-running inconsistencies between cluster nodes

fields.description:
Because git-lfs on the client relies on a pre-push hook to actually upload LFS files, it is possible for a user to complete a push *without* uploading any LFS files.

This may happen if a user is working from a new clone or worktree and has the LFS filters installed in their global .gitconfig but does not have the LFS hook properly installed in their repo's .git/hooks directory.

Because LFS files are uploaded from a pre-push hook, Bitbucket Server should be able to detect when a push contains LFS pointers to files that weren't already pushed to or otherwise don't exist in LFS storage. In this case, the offending push should be rejected.

Currently, if this were to happen the error wouldn't be caught until much later, and it would be caught by our build server instead of by the user or by Bitbucket Server.
fields.summary: Reject push to git-lfs-enabled repo if LFS files don't exist on the server
